content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <metadata> <idinfo> <citation> <citeinfo> <origin>Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Mapping and Boundary Branch</origin> <pubdate>20101005</pubdate> <title>Outer Continental Shelf Lease Blocks - Atlantic Region NAD83</title> <geoform Sync="TRUE">vector digital data</geoform> <serinfo> <sername>Digital Offshore Cadastre</sername> <issue>current</issue> </serinfo> <pubinfo> <pubplace>Herndon, Virginia</pubplace> <publish>Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Mapping and Boundary Branch</publish> </pubinfo> <onlink>http://www.boem.gov/Oil-and-Gas-Energy-Program/Mapping-and-Data/ATL_BLKCLIP(3).aspx</onlink> <onlink>http://www.boem.gov/Oil-and-Gas-Energy-Program/Mapping-and-Data/Atlantic.aspx</onlink> <lworkcit> <citeinfo> <origin>Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Mapping and Boundary Branch</origin> <pubdate>20101005</pubdate> <title>BOEM Offshore Cadastral Data</title> <geoform>map</geoform> <pubinfo> <pubplace>Herndon, Virginia</pubplace> <publish>Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Mapping and Boundary Branch</publish> </pubinfo> </citeinfo> </lworkcit> </citeinfo> </citation> <descript> <abstract> This data set contains OCS block outlines in ArcGIS shape file format for  the BOEM Atlantic Region.  OCS blocks are used to define small geographic  areas within an Official Protraction Diagram (OPD) for leasing and administrative purposes.  These blocks have been clipped along the Submerged Lands Act  (SLA) boundary and along the Continental Shelf Boundaries.  Additional details  are available from:  http://www.boemre.gov/itd/pubs/1999/99-0006.pdf Because GIS projection and topology functions can change or generalize coordinates, and because shapefiles can not represent true arcs, these GIS files are considered to be approximate and are NOT an OFFICIAL record for the exact block coordinates or areas. The Official Protraction Diagrams (OPDs) and Supplemental Official Block Diagrams (SOBDs) serve as the legal definition for BOEM offshore boundary coordinates and area descriptions. </abstract> <purpose> These block polygons and other cadastre information the BOEM produces are generated in accordance with 30 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 256.8 to support Federal land ownership and mineral resource management. </purpose> <supplinf> The BOEM is making its existing cadastre data available at http://www.boem.gov/Oil-and-Gas-Energy-Program/Mapping-and-Data/Index.aspx.  These data include Official Protraction Diagrams (OPDs), and Supplemental Official OCS Block Diagrams (SOBDs) in pdf format, and digital spatial data in ArcGIS shapefile format. </supplinf> </descript> <timeperd> <timeinfo> <rngdates> <begdate>2005</begdate> <enddate>2008</enddate> </rngdates> </timeinfo> <current>publication date</current> </timeperd> <status> ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.1850</native> <crossref> <citeinfo> <origin>Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Mapping and Boundary Branch</origin> <pubdate>2001-2010</pubdate> <title>Supplemental Official OCS Block Diagrams (SOBDs)</title> <edition>current version</edition> <geoform>diagram</geoform> <pubinfo> <pubplace>Herndon, Virginia</pubplace> <publish>Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Mapping and Boundary Branch</publish> </pubinfo> <othercit> SOBDs contain official coordinate and area descriptions for individual blocks. </othercit> <onlink>http://www.boem.gov/Oil-and-Gas-Energy-Program/Mapping-and-Data/Atlantic.aspx</onlink> <lworkcit> <citeinfo> <origin>Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Mapping and Boundary Branch</origin> <pubdate>2001-2010</pubdate> <title>BOEM Offshore Cadastral Data</title> </citeinfo> </lworkcit> </citeinfo> </crossref> <crossref> <citeinfo> <origin>Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Mapping and Boundary Branch</origin> <pubdate>2001-2010</pubdate> <title>Official Protraction Diagrams (OPDs)</title> <pubinfo> <pubplace>Herndon, Virginia</pubplace> <publish>Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Mapping and Boundary Branch</publish> </pubinfo> <othercit> Atlantic Region OPDs show the OCS blocks for an area approximately two degrees wide and one degree high. </othercit> <lworkcit> <citeinfo> <origin>Bureau of Ocean Energy Management</origin> <pubdate>2001-2010</pubdate> <title>BOEM Offshore Cadastral Data</title> </citeinfo> </lworkcit> </citeinfo> </crossref> </idinfo> <dataqual> <logic>The file is believed to be free of topologic errors.</logic> <complete> All federal blocks from the Submerged Lands Act Boundary (3 mile line) out to the Continental Shelf Boundary or Limit of Protraction are included. </complete> <posacc> <horizpa> <horizpar> Coordinates values have been computed to .00000001 of a degree, but this shapefile is considered to be approximate.  Where differences occur between the shapefile and the OPD and SOBD diagrams, the diagrams take precidence. This shapefile was created by extracting the X-Y UTM coordinates from the TIMS database.  In order to create this Regional shapefile, which spans multiple UTM zones, all coordinates were re-projected to a single UTM zone (Zone 18).  This file was then re-projected to geographic for distribution purposes.  This resulted in some distortion (up to 0.009 meters) at the far East and West edges of the shapefile. </horizpar> </horizpa> </posacc> <lineage> <srcinfo> <srccite> <citeinfo> <origin>BOEM</origin> <pubdate>Unpublished Material</pubdate> <title>BOEM Technical Information Management System</title> <geoform>database</geoform> <pubinfo> <pubplace>Herndon, VA</pubplace> <publish>Bureau of Ocean Energy Management</publish> </pubinfo> </citeinfo> </srccite> <typesrc>digital</typesrc> <srctime> <timeinfo> <rngdates> <begdate>2005</begdate> <enddate>2008</enddate> </rngdates> </timeinfo> <srccurr>publication date</srccurr> </srctime> <srccitea>TIMS</srccitea> <srccontr>Coordinates and attributes for block polygons.</srccontr> </srcinfo> <procstep> <procdesc> In house programs were used to protract the blocks on a UTM grid for the offshore areas, and to intersect those blocks with various boundaries including the SLA and CSB boundaries.  The resulting points were then stored in the TIMS database.  Other in-house programs were used to create an ArcInfo Coverage from the data stored in the TIMS database.  That coverage was converted into a shapefile using ArcGIS, and any portions of blocks landward of the SLA boundary or seaward of the CSB boundary were removed.  The shapefile was further "disolved" to remove any other internal boundary lines, leaving only the block outlines. </procdesc> <srcused>TIMS</srcused> <procdate>2009</procdate> <proccont> <cntinfo>
